column7: Evaluation of X-ray irradiation on the uveal melanoma cells in 2D and 3D in vitro models
column8: Uveal melanoma (UM) is an aggressive form of cancer that affects the cells in uveal melanocytes. Patients are diagnosed late, and over 50% of them will develop metastases in liver. The prognosis is very poor, because currently there are no sufficient methods for treating. Radiotherapy plays crucial role in the treatment of UM. In cell cultures, radiotherapy has been found to induce DNA damage and cell death. In 3D models, it has shown promising efficacy in targeting its architecture, providing valuable insights into radiotherapy potential impact on tumor growth and invasion. We choose two in vitro models: 2D (clones) and 3D (spheroids) and examine their applicability in X-ray radiotherapy. Using tumors collected from patients we derived unique UM cell lines and immortal LX-2 cell line to mimic liver niche, which were used to create our models. They were treated with different doses of radiation. We investigated differences between effects after radiotherapy. Results shows that 2D model was quite sensitive to X-ray radiotherapy, while spheroids were almost completely resistant to the same doses of radiation. In 2D we can observe the effect in clones’ morphology and numbers of surviving cells depending on the used X-ray dose. In case of spheroids, two different proliferation tests gave consistent results, showing that cells survival was high, even under 10 Gy dose, and similar to control. It might be caused by several factors, mainly by hypoxia inside spheroids. During radiotherapy spheroid can loosen their structure, dead cells from cortical layer fell out, but inside hypoxic necrotic core cells were more resistant to radiation and started proliferation. In vitro studies on the effectiveness of radiotherapy for UM cannot be based only on 2D models, as they provide overly optimistic results. Studies must also be conducted on 3D models, which provide more realistic results by providing conditions more similar to those encountered during radiotherapy of solid tumors.

column7: Antimicrobial activity of Mg doped ZnO nanoparticles
column8: According to WHO repport (2022), problem of antimicrobial resistance is considered a leading global public health issue with the increasing number of infections caused by drug-resistant microorganisms. ZnO nanoparticles (NPs) show notable antimicrobial activity due to interactions with bacterial surfaces and enzymes. ZnO-NPs are non-toxic to eukaryotic cells, which is an advantage for possible applications. Magnesium is also characterised by its antibacterial properties and has high biocompatibility for human cells. In order to increase the antibacterial properties exhibited by ZnO NPs, Mg doping of ZnO matrix was proposed. The aim of our study was to evaluate the antimicrobial performance of ZnO NPs doped with different percentages of Mg (1% mol., 5% mol. and 10% mol.). Two doping precursors (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and MgCl2 ּ·6H2O) were also evaluated. Mg doped ZnO NPs were prepared using eco-friendly microwave hydrothermal technique. NPs were tested on 8 bacterial strains: Proteus sp., Salmonella sp., Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Streptococcus B haemolyticus, Staphylococcus aureus methicillin-resistant, Staphylococcus aureus ATTC and Staphylococcus epidermidis utilizing established protocol of modified disk diffusion method. Following 24h of bacterial growth, the inhibition zone was measured and photographed. Results showed that a more effective Mg precursor was the MgCl2·6H2O. ZnO NPs doped with 1% mol. and 5% mol. Mg exhibited stronger antibacterial activity than 10% mol. Mg. We reckon that 10% mol Mg doping may have severely altered the crystaline structure of the NPs and thus been responsible for the loss of the observed antibacterial activity.

column7: Low-frequency electromagnetic field (50 Hz, 1.5 mT, 24h, 48h) can influence “stem cell fate”
column8: Background: Electromagnetic field can affect the biology and cellular processes (such as proliferation, differentiation, cell cycle, and metabolism) of mesenchymal stem cells and thus modulate their “fate”. Researchers unveiled its positive and negative impact on cells depending on parameters and time of exposure. In search of stem cell-based therapy, it can be used as a preconditioning factor for regenerative medicine purposes. Therefore, it seems crucial to understand how electromagnetic field, in specific parameters and doses, impact stem cell biology.  Methods: Commercially available, human adipose-derived stem cells were exposed continuously to low-frequency electromagnetic fields (50 Hz; 1.5 mT) in vitro. After 24 and 48 hours, total RNA was isolated, and complementary DNA was synthesized. Next, Tuj-1, Sox9, Runx2, and Numb gene expression were analyzed with the quantitative PCR method. Data were analyzed with one-way ANOVA using the Tukey test. Results: Electromagnetic field (50 Hz; 1.5 mT) can statistically significantly influence the expression of Tuj 1 gene, which is related to neurogenesis after 48h of stimulation. Moreover, it impacts chondrogenic gene expression such as Sox9 after 24 and 48 hours of exposure. However, it does not affect significantly the osteogenic marker expression Runx2 as well as the Numb gene expression associated with the symmetric and asymmetric stem cell division pathway. Conclusions: Tested electromagnetic doses may “force” ASCs to redefine their stem cell fate, alter their reprogramming decision, and initiate differentiation processes. It is even more interesting, that morphologically it is unidentifiable. Further research on differentiation markers and the analysis of cellular pathways such as Notch-Numb involved in cell division should be conducted.

column7: Interaction of Intravenous Immunoglobulin Products with C1q Protein
column8: Quality control laboratories currently lack a high-throughput, reliable, and convenient method for testing the anticomplementary activity of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg). The primary reason for increased anticomplementary activity of IVIg is the presence of aggregated immunoglobulins. To enhance patient safety, a new method has been proposed based on measuring the binding level of immunoglobulins to the C1q protein. C1q is a subcomponent of the C1 complex, initiating the classical pathway of the complement cascade. This study aims to determine if the extent of binding to C1q can reliably measure the level of aggregates in IVIg  products. The characterization of IVIg will be performed using size exclusion chromatography,  and its binding to C1q will be measured in an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The  IVIg material will be stressed under different conditions to increase the content of aggregated  immunoglobulins and will be compared with material that did, or did not cause adverse reactions in patients after administration. Furthermore, the sensitivity and detection limit of the  C1q-ELISA will be assessed. The results will determine whether the C1q-binding ELISA-based method can produce reliable results when measuring the level of aggregates in IVIg.

column7: Susceptibility of clinical isolates of Candida spp. in planktonic and biofilm form to antifungal substances
column8: Candida albicans is the most extensively studied and prevalent fungal pathogen in humans. In most cases, C. albicans exists as a harmless commensal in the intestine, urogenital tract, and skin. However, under specific conditions, it can become an opportunistic pathogen, causing infections of varying severity - from superficial skin infections to life-threatening systemic infections. Resistance to antifungal drugs poses a serious therapeutic challenge and can lead to treatment failures and prolonged hospitalization. The study aimed to assess the susceptibility of the nine clinical strains and the reference strain ATCC 10231 of Candida spp. to antifungal substances, two antibiotics: miconazole and 5-fluorocytosine, and three antiseptics: Octenisept, Braunol, and Prontosan. The sensitivity of strains was tested using methods recommended by EUCAST and CLSI. For all strains, minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) and minimum bactericidal concentrations (MBC) were determined. The analysis was performed for all C. albicans strains in planktonic and on the biofilm forms.  It has been demonstrated that the analyzed strains exhibited varied sensitivity depending on the tested substance concentration and cell form. Compared to the reference strain, the clinical strains were less sensitive depending on the applied substance. Results show that 55% of the strains analyzed showed reduced sensitivity to the tested antiseptics compared to the reference strain, while for antibiotics it was 50%. The most resistant strain turned out to be strain 3440, which showed greater resistance to both antibiotics and antiseptics. Biofilm formation and sensitivity varied across strains, influenced by type, incubation time, glucose levels in the TSB medium, and the antifungal substance used. The study reveals increased resistance in Candida spp. strains could complicate treatment efforts due to varied sensitivity to antifungals and antiseptics.

column7: Efficient recognition of double-stranded RNA does not require activation of the interferon pathway
column8: The recent COVID pandemic has made it clear that viruses are one of the biggest threats to human health and pose serious problems to healthcare systems worldwide. Zoonotic and epidemic diseases such as COVID-19, influenza and many others are caused by highly pathogenic RNA viruses. During the replication of RNA viruses, highly immunogenic double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) molecules are produced. The aim of our research was to expand current knowledge on how epitranscriptomic modifications of viral RNA affect host cell-virus interplay. To mimic viral infection, in vitro transcribed double-stranded RNA (IVT dsRNA) carrying various chemical modifications was introduced into mammalian cells. RNA sequencing and proteomic analysis revealed that the 5’ end of dsRNA is exclusively responsible for antiviral and inflammatory immune responses mediated by RIG-I-like receptors. Further analyses revealed that the presence of the double-stranded RNA structure itself does not lead to inflammation, but leads to a global inhibition of protein synthesis via activation of the OAS/RNaseL and PKR pathways and thus cell growth. Furthermore, we showed that among three most common post-transcriptional modifications, i.e. psudouridine, 5-methylcytosine and N6-methyladenosine, the presence of m6A shields dsRNA from recognition by OAS proteins.

column7: Fusion Taq DNA polymerases as a diagnostic tool in qPCR and RT-qPCR techniques.
column8: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) methods are widely used tools in molecular diagnostic. They're efficient and cost-effective way to copy small specific DNA or RNA with reliable result. Although the overall method is easy the problem often lies in the material used for diagnostic purposes like clinical or environmental samples. Complications such as long templates, templates rich in GC pairs or inhibitors present in this type of samples can drastically reduce the yield of the ongoing reaction. Modified polymerases i.e., fusion DNA polymerases can help solving those issues. They're DNA polymerases fused with DNA binding protein (or only with its functional domain) which has the natural ability to bind single or double stranded DNA. It was found that this fusion influences many properties of used enzyme and allow for effective qPCR and RT-qPCR reactions directly in clinical samples. Modified polymerases enable both reverse transcription and dsDNA synthesis to be carried out faster and more efficiently, and confer partial resistance to inhibitors present in clinical samples. My research focuses on Taq DNA polymerases, which are widely used in molecular diagnostics, and the properties they can improve and/or acquire after the modifications I introduce.  I would like to present current knowledge about the impact of modifications of Taq DNA polymerases on the improvement of PCR and RT-PCR methods, as well as share the progress of my research on obtaining new fusion DNA polymerases emphasizing their possible application in molecular diagnostics.

column7: Development of phage-based tool with the potential to treat antibiotic-resistant gonorrhea
column8: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is an etiological agent of gonorrhea, the second most common sexually transmitted disease.  The emergence of new antibiotic-resistant strains indicates that research on new alternatives for treatment is highly relevant. We’re investigating different approaches to apply phages as antimicrobials against Neisseria.  In order to perform phage hunting, environmental samples (sewage water and turf soil) were filtered and concentrated. Such samples were mixed with bacteria and added to top-agar in double layer agar plates to perform screening for lytic phages against Neisseria as host. We used wild-type and mutant (in terms of antiviral defense systems) strains. Any plaques were cut out and enriched in liquid or solid culture. After concentration, lysates were titrated by spot assay. Lytic phages found in turf soil were able to infect a wild-type bacteria and one of the clinical strains. Phage particles were visualized using TEM analysis. Within a molecular approach, Neisseria prophages were screened for genes encoding proteins with potential lytic activity.  We selected 4 genes from dsDNA prophage sequences: 506, 508, 1095 and 1649. They potentially encode two depolymerases, holin-endolysin complex and lysozyme, respectively. Cloning and expression optimization of 506 and 508 was performed using the pET28a(+) system in E. coli. Further on, we’ll be testing their lytic activity (alone or enhanced by permeabilization reagent) against N. gonorrhoeae by spot test and during planktonic growth or biofilm formation. Newly discovered lytic phage show the ability to limit in vitro growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae.  We predict that phage proteins can act as antimicrobials as well. Both approaches have a great potential to help develop new treatments for gonorrhea.

column7: A survey of protective effect of melatonin against trifluoperazine induced genotoxicity in peripheral blood lymphocytes via micronucleus assay
column8: Introduction: Trifluoperazine is a commonly prescribed antipsychotic for schizophrenia  management, but its use has been associated with genotoxicity and oxidative damage,  attributed to apoptosis induction and inhibition of DNA repair. In contrast, melatonin, an  endogenous hormone with potent antioxidant properties, presents a promising avenue  for reducing such adverse effects. This study sets out to investigate the protective role  of melatonin against trifluoperazine-induced oxidative genotoxicity. Objective: The primary objective of this study is to assess the efficacy of melatonin as  an antioxidant agent in alleviating oxidative-induced genotoxicity induced by  trifluoperazine in human lymphocytes. Specifically, the study aims to elucidate the  potential therapeutic effect of melatonin in mitigating adverse effects associated with  prolonged trifluoperazine treatment. Materials and Methods: Human lymphocyte samples obtained from a healthy male  volunteer were divided into experimental groups, including negative controls, cisplatin  controls, trifluoperazine-treated groups at concentrations of 50 μM and 100 μM, and a  trifluoperazine-melatonin group at 100 μM. Genotoxicity was evaluated using the  micronucleus assay, while lipid peroxidation and glutathione oxidation levels were  measured to assess oxidative damage. column7: Characteristics of commercial Milk Thistle oil
column8: Milk Thistle (Silybum marianum L. Gaertn), an annual or biennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Asteraceae family, exhibits remarkable adaptability to diverse soil and environmental conditions across continents. Over two millennia, Milk Thistle has been utilized as a remedy for various diseases, particularly focusing on its efficacy in treating liver conditions such as hepatitis, cirrhosis, and fibrosis. Additionally, it is recognized for its pharmacological effects, including antidiabetic, cardioprotective, and immune-modulatory properties. The primary pharmaceutical compound found in milk thistle is a mixture of flavonolignans, collectively known as silymarin, consisting mainly of silibinin, silychristin, silidianin, and isosilybin. Additionally, milk thistle seeds have a high oil content (20-30%). This oil is rich in unsaturated fatty acids, notably linoleic and oleic acid, which offer health benefits in preventing arteriosclerosis, diabetes, and cancer. Moreover, Milk Thistle seed oil is recommended as a potential source of natural antioxidant due to its abundance of vitamin E. In this study, we analyzed the properties of commercial Milk Thistle oil, focusing on key parameters such as acid value, peroxide value, fatty acid composition, and their distribution between sn-1,3 and sn-2 positions of triacylglycerols. Furthermore, we assessed the total phenolic content, antioxidant activity, and oxidative stability of the oil.

column7: Combined use of paclitaxel and novel mitosis inhibitors as a potential anticancer strategy
column8: The key function of the microtubules and mitotic spindle in cell division (also determining the potential of cancer cells to proliferate) make them an important target in cancer therapy. Therefore, microtubule-targeting agents (MTAs) remain the most important class of conventional chemotherapeutics. However, narrow therapeutic index and multidrug resistance encourage the search for new drugs or new strategies to improve anticancer therapy outcomes and decrease side effects. Taxanes (paclitaxel, PTX), docetaxel, and carbasitaxel), which belong to MTAs, have revolutionized the therapy of solid tumors. However, their hydrophobic nature as well as peripheral neuropathies are among the major limitations and adverse effects of taxane therapy. Combining taxanes with tubulin polymerization inhibitors is one of the strategies that increase the effectiveness of treatment. However, this approach involves high-dose administration of chemotherapeutic agents and causes many side effects. It was recently shown (both in vitro and in vivo) that a combination of low and safe doses of PTX and tubulin polymerization inhibitors (but also clinically insignificant doses when the compounds are used alone) is a promising strategy that allows to the reduction of toxicity.  This study is aimed to evaluate the effect of novel pyridine (S1, S22) and benzofuran (13b, 14) inhibitors of tubulin polymerization on the anticancer properties of low doses of PTX. The anticancer effect of compounds applied in combination with PTX was evaluated against the melanoma A375 and cervical HeLa cell line. PrestoBlue assay was used to the identification of optimal concentrations of combination systems (PTX + S1/S2/13b/14), which exhibited significantly greater (compared to individual compounds) anticancer activity against cervical HeLa cancer cells.

column7: Establishment of the 2d and 3d in vitro skin cancer models to study the interplay between tissue remodeling and immune response
column8: The typical skin cell models (monolayers) used for assessing compounds impact suffer from lack of accuracy in the real tissue representation. The problem intensifies when it comes to skin cancer models (1-2). This can be overcome by using advanced models such as skin equivalents and spheres. Although equivalents are more popular, spheres better reflect the tumor microenvironment, due to their specific structure (3). Therefore, we aim to create complex skin cancer models (2D and spheres), and next to compare their secretion of tissue remodeling and immune factors.  In this study, cell spheres were created using the established method of limiting cell adhesion (LCA) (4). Various cell lines including human melanocytes (NHEM) and melanoma cells (A375, G361, WM115, WM266-4) were cultured. Initially, for each cell line sphere formation potential was assessed in a monoculture, followed by a coculture with mast cells (LUVA). Cell aggregation dynamics and sphere morphology were observed using a cell culture monitoring system. Matrix metalloproteinases (MMP) activity and secretion of interleukins (IL) were analyzed through gelatin zymography assay and dot blot, respectively. Our results indicate that usability of every cell line in a model relies on its properties. Although, the LCA method assures the creation of stable, round-shaped and repeatable spheres, they differed in morphology depending on the applied cell type. The cell lines able to create spheres, aggregated in the first few hours. At first mast cells smoothly incorporated into the tumorsphere, however, with time their migration was noted. Finally, a significant difference of MMP activity and secreted IL in 2D and 3D skin cancer models was observed. column7: Exploring Hormetic Effects: Sulforaphane's Role in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer via In Vitro and In Vivo Models

column7: Identification, superantigen toxin gene profile and antimicrobial resistance of staphylococci isolated from nasal cavities of healthy reindeer (Rangifer tarandus caribou)
column8: The study aimed to analyze staphylococcal microbiota of the nasal cavity of the healthy reindeer kept on different farms located in Poland, Finland, and Germany. The research included the identification of staphylococcal species, evaluation of the prevalence of genes encoding enterotoxins, staphylococcal enterotoxin-like proteins, exfoliative toxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin 1, and the detection of antimicrobial resistance. In total, 76 staphylococci were isolated from 31 swab samples (14 collected in Poland, 3 in Finland, and 14 in Germany). Based on PCR-RFLP analysis of the gap gene using AluI and HpyCH4V enzymes, the isolates were identified as: Staphylococcus equorum (24%), S. succinus (16%) S. sciuri (14%), S. lentus (11%), S. chromogenes (8%), S. xylosus (7%), S. vitulinus (3%), S. simulans (1%), S. auricularis (1%), S. agnetis (1%). The remaining staphylococci (14%) were identified only at the genus level and were referred to as Staphylococcus spp. One species identified from the Polish herd, S. chromogenes, was part of the Staphylococcus intermedius group (SIG). It was also found that none of the strains harbored genes encoding superantigens. The incidence and number of strains resistant to antimicrobials were found to be bacterial species but not herd-dependent. The highest percentage of antibiotic resistance was found for S. sciuri. The most frequent resistance was observed to clindamycin (22%). The findings of this study proved that, regardless of the locations, nasal cavities of healthy reindeer are colonized by the non-toxigenic, however, antimicrobial-resistant staphylococci.

column7: The effect of polystyrene nanoplastic on the electrophysiology of intestinal epithelium – insights from Caco-2 cell model
column8: The problem of environmental pollution (such as particulate matter and micro- and nanoplastics) and its influence on living organisms has become extremely important. Nevertheless, the knowledge of their effects on human epithelial tissues is still insufficient. It has been already proven that micro- and nanoplastics act as vectors enabling the spread of organic pollutants, they interact with heavy metals and show cell-toxicity. The information whether and how nanoplastics can affect transepithelial water and ion transport is still limited.   This research aimed to investigate the effects of polysterene nanoplastics (diameter of 100 nm) on human intestinal epithelial cell line Caco-2. Following the exposure to polystyrene nanoplastic (PS-NP.), its cytotoxicity was assessed by MTT assay. The effect of PS-NP on mucus secretion was assessed by Alcian blue staining. Additionally, the changes of ion transport across Caco-2 cell monolayers in the presence of PS-NP was assessed by short-circuit current measurements in Ussing chamber.   The results show that nanoplastics affect the ion transport across the cell monolayers and lead to increased mucus secretion. The presence of nanoplastics decreased CFTR channel activity, however, increased the activity of other chloride channels. Application of ion transporting proteins modulators allowed determining the TMEM16a involvement in increased chloride currents. Increased activity of TMEM16a may also be responsible for enhanced mucus secretion which is a possible defensive mechanism of Caco-2 cells against nanoplastics.   We expect that our research will expand knowledge regarding the potential toxicity of nanoplastics on biological systems.

column7: Optical fiber sensor for detecting inflammatory markers in complex fluids
column8: Developing optical fiber-based sensors to detect inflammatory markers implies many advantages. The main of them is the possibility of conducting analysis directly in the human body, e.g. intravascularly. Unfortunately, body fluids, including blood and serum, are very complex. The biological particles they contain strongly disrupt the functioning of sensors. Therefore, it is important to develop modifications of the sensor surface to eliminate the influence of background and increase the selectivity.   The aim of the research was to develop fiber-optic sensor for detecting inflammatory markers in complex fluids, specifically in serum. In order to achieve satisfactory results, it was essential to optimize the chemical modification of the fiber. The various composition of oxide surfaces and silanes was analyzed. This was important for the effective immobilization of antibodies that selectively recognise the target molecules. Then the most effective method of surface blocking was investigated, to eliminate non-specific interactions of serum components with the sensor surface. Final measurements were performed in simple microfluidic device, comprising a cover glass and a channel made in polydimethylsiloxane. Optical fibers were placed inside the prepared microchannel and samples were examined under continuous flow. In order to investigate the molecular interactions between the sensing element (antibodies) and the analyte (proteins), spectral changes were analyzed in the wavelength range of 1500-1600 nm. Interestingly, during the research a fragment of a 3D model of human blood vessels on a 1:1 scale was also used.   In conclusion, the research resulted in the development of a sensor that allows the detection of inflammatory markers in complex fluids, especially in serum. In further research, we plan to continue to optimize the sensor for better sensitivity. column7: Identification, superantigen toxin gene profile and antimicrobial resistance of staphylococci isolated from nasal cavities of healthy reindeer (Rangifer tarandus caribou)
column8: The study aimed to analyze staphylococcal microbiota of the nasal cavity of the healthy reindeer kept on different farms located in Poland, Finland, and Germany. The research included the identification of staphylococcal species, evaluation of the prevalence of genes encoding enterotoxins, staphylococcal enterotoxin-like proteins, exfoliative toxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin 1, and the detection of antimicrobial resistance. In total, 76 staphylococci were isolated from 31 swab samples (14 collected in Poland, 3 in Finland, and 14 in Germany). Based on PCR-RFLP analysis of the gap gene using AluI and HpyCH4V enzymes, the isolates were identified as: Staphylococcus equorum (24%), S. succinus (16%) S. sciuri (14%), S. lentus (11%), S. chromogenes (8%), S. xylosus (7%), S. vitulinus (3%), S. simulans (1%), S. auricularis (1%), S. agnetis (1%). The remaining staphylococci (14%) were identified only at the genus level and were referred to as Staphylococcus spp. One species identified from the Polish herd, S. chromogenes, was part of the Staphylococcus intermedius group (SIG). It was also found that none of the strains harbored genes encoding superantigens. The incidence and number of strains resistant to antimicrobials were found to be bacterial species but not herd-dependent. The highest percentage of antibiotic resistance was found for S. sciuri. The most frequent resistance was observed to clindamycin (22%). The findings of this study proved that, regardless of the locations, nasal cavities of healthy reindeer are colonized by the non-toxigenic, however, antimicrobial-resistant staphylococci.

column7: Bacterial cellulose covered with different types of waxes as an ecological, home-use food packaging material
column8: Plastics have become the most commonly used material in every field of industry, especially in food packaging. Therefore, more ecological solutions are now being intensively sought. Recently a new product has appeared on the market – Bee’s Wraps – a biodegradable alternative to traditional food packaging made of cotton and beeswax. The high price makes them not available to everyone. Recent research showed that bacterial cellulose (BC) can be used as an ideal food packaging material. This biopolymer is produced by non-pathogenic environmental bacteria. It was confirmed that BC is safe, non-toxic, fully biodegradable and can be used in the food industry.   The aim of this study was to prepare ecological food packaging material based on BC impregnated with various types of waxes: beeswax and plant waxes.   The production process involved BC biosynthesis by Komagataeibacter xylinus ATCC 53524, followed by purification, homogenization, and drying or lyophilization. Optimalization of the production process included different process parameters: pulp volume, pulp density, and freezing temperature. The foils were covered with various types of waxes using the ironing machine. Samples were subjected to further analysis such as macro- and microstructure analysis, water properties (swelling ratio, water permeability), contact angle and antimicrobial properties.    The foil production method used in this study allowed to obtain an innovative food packaging based on BC covered with wax. A smooth and even structure of foils was achieved by drying the cellulose pulp mixed with water in a ratio of 1:2. Covering the foils with wax gave it specific plastic properties. The results showed that wax-impregnated BC films are hydrophobic. It was confirmed that obtained samples have antimicrobial and against both Gram-positive (S. aureus) and Gram-negative (E. coli) bacteria. This solution can provide cheap, ecological and safe food packaging for home use.

column7: End-face optical fiber sensor for detecting inflammatory markers in serum
column8: Developing optical fiber-based sensors to detect inflammatory markers implies many advantages. The main of them is the possibility of conducting analysis directly in the human body, e.g. intravascularly. Unfortunately, body fluids, including blood and serum, are very complex. The biological particles they contain strongly disrupt the functioning of sensors. Therefore, it is important to develop modifications of the sensor surface to eliminate the influence of background and increase the selectivity. The aim of the research was to develop an end-face optical fiber sensor for detecting inflammatory markers (e.g. myeloperoxidase (MPO)) in complex fluids, specifically in serum. It was essential to optimize the chemical modification of the fiber. The various compositions of oxide surfaces and silanes were analyzed. This was important for the effective immobilization of antibodies that selectively recognise the inflammatory markers. Then the most effective method of surface blocking was investigated, to eliminate non-specific interactions of serum components with the sensor surface. Final measurements were performed in a simple microfluidic device, comprising a cover glass and a channel made in polydimethylsiloxane. Optical fibers were placed inside the prepared microchannel and samples were examined under continuous flow. In order to investigate the molecular interactions between the sensing element (antibodies) and the analyte (proteins), spectral changes were analyzed in the wavelength range of 1500-1600 nm. Interestingly, during the research a fragment of a 3D model of human blood vessels on a 1:1 scale was also used. In conclusion, the study resulted in the development of a sensor that allows the detection of inflammatory markers in serum. In further research, we plan to continue to optimize the sensor for higher sensitivity. column7: Stapled peptides as promising antibacterial agents
column8: Antimicrobial resistance is a growing concern in healthcare, as the overuse and misuse of antibiotics have led to an exponential increase in resistant bacterial strains. Unfortunately, most antibiotics in clinical use today were developed in the 1980s – the golden age of antibiotic therapy. The imbalance between the demand for new drugs and their supply has prompted a search for novel strategies to combat resistant microbes.  	Modern approaches in drug discovery employ short antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) produced by the immune systems of various organisms. Most AMPs act by disrupting the bacterial cell membrane through the interaction of hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts of amphipathic peptide helices. Nevertheless, most AMPs require a lipid environment to acquire this structure.  	We hypothesized that stabilizing the AMP structure could enhance its antibacterial activity due to adopting a membrane-active helix already in an aqueous solution. To test this hypothesis, we modified the AMPs using hydrocarbon stapling [1,2]. Our results indicate that stapled peptides adopt a stable helical structure, exhibit enhanced bactericidal activity, remain stable in proteolytic enzyme solutions, and demonstrate no toxicity to eukaryotic cells, including red blood cells [1,2]. Moreover, we are developing a computational approach to design new modified AMPs containing non-natural amino acids. Our studies will aid the future design of AMPs with improved bactericidal activity and biostability. column7: Exploring Genetic diversity and Host Associations of Leaf Blister Mites (Eriophyes spp.) on Fruit trees
column8: Eriophyoid mites (Acari: Eriophyoidea) are noteworthy among phytophagous mites as they cause serious damage to their host plants through direct feeding and transmission of plant viruses. A great majority of mite species that are transmitting plant pathogens belong to the superfamily Eriophyoidea. Majority of the eriophyoid mites are host-specific, with just a few mites displaying a broader host range. In this study, we aimed to investigate if leaf blister mites (Eriophyes spp.) inhabiting apple (Malus spp.), pear (Pyrus spp.), rowan (Sorbus spp.), and quince (Cydonia spp.) are conspecific or represent distinct species. Specifically, mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COX1) region was amplified and sequenced from aforementioned mites. Subsequently, phylogenetic trees were constructed using maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference methods. Our study revealed the presence of host-dependent genetic variation in leaf blister mites. This study shows that mites inhabiting apple, pear, rowan, and quince were Eriophyes mali, E. pyri, E. sorbi, and E. orientalis respectively. However, huge genetic variability observed within E. mali, E. pyri, and E. sorbi suggests further cryptic speciation. Presented analysis advances our knowledge of eriophyoid mites evolution and diversity. Furthermore, our study lays the groundwork for future research into their ecology and management strategies.

column7: Non- gold mediated TRAP protein nanocage. A promising tool for smart drug delivery
column8: Protein nanocages are hollow-like structures with clearly defined external, internal, and inter-subunit surfaces. The field of the protein nanocages can be roughly divided into: natural protein nanocages like viral capsids and artificial protein nanocages, like TRAP. The trp RNA-binding attenuation protein (TRAP) is the 74 amino acid-long protein from the species Geobacillus stearothermophilus. Eleven units of the TRAP proteins self-assemble into the ring-like structure and it takes part in the regulation of the l-tryptophan metabolism. The engineered TRAP protein contains the mutation K35C which is located on the ring’s rim position. The addition of gold promotes the self-assembly of the TRAP rings into a cage-like structure with a molecular size of around 2 Megadaltons.  In my research, I have designed two other mutants with metal-binding sites. All proteins were overexpressed in E.coli and purified via the standard laboratory techniques.  Studied mutants were shown to make cage-like structures upon mixing with zinc and cobalt. All of the studied protein nanocages possess very similar architecture and biochemical properties. Both cobalt and zinc TRAP protein nanocages are readily disassembled in the presence of the chelating agents (EDTA) and in the acidic and alkaline pH. However, once the pH is neutral back and the slight excess of the divalent cations are added in the presence of EDTA, all studied non-gold mediated TRAP protein nanocages are reassembled. This feature of the TRAP nanocage makes it a promising tool for the smart delivery of drugs to the target site. In conclusion, the TRAP protein nanocage is a unique artificial protein nanocage. The possibility to easily assemble/reassemble it in relatively mild conditions could make the non-gold mediated TRAP protein nanocage an excellent choice for future drug delivery studies.  1 Malay, A, D. et al. column7: Detection of virulence genes among Enterococcus spp. strains  isolated from the animal farm environment
column8: Bacteria of the Enterococcus genus are opportunistic microorganisms. An important source of pathogenic strains, especially E. faecium and E. faecalis spieces, is livestock. Increased virulence of strains is often associated with the presence of various virulence factors. The aim of this study was to assess the frequency of genes encoding selected virulence factors in E. faecium and E. faecalis strains isolated from the poultry house environment. The material for the study consisted of 40 strains from the poultry house environment isolated from different sites. The isolated strains were indentified using MALDI-TOF MS technique. DNA of the bacteria was extracted using a thermal method, and conventional polymerase chain reactions (PCR) were used to screen for the presence of selected virulence genes. The study evaluated the presence of the endocarditis- and biofilm-associated pili genetic locus (ebpABC), pili (pil), enterococcal endocarditis antigen (efaAfs) and gelatinase (gelE). The PCR products were subjected to electrophoresis in a 1.5% agarose gel.   The study found 40 Enterococcus spp. strains, of which 35 (87.5%) belonged to the E. faecium species, and 5 (12.5%) represented the E. faecalis species. The largest number of strains came from samples taken from the wall (n=9, 22.5%) and from the drinker/feeder (n=9, 22.5%). The presence of selected virulence genes was found in 6 (15.0%) isolated strains, of which 5 (83.3%) represented E. faecalis species. The study found one (2.5%) strain of E.faecalis carrying all the virulence genes included in the study.  The study showed the presence of Enterococcus spp. species in poultry house environment. Most of the selected genes were present in E. faecalis strains. Due to frequent human contact with livestock, the study of the presence of virulence genes among strains from the animal farm environment may provide valuable information on the reasons for the increased virulence of pathogenic Enterococcus spp. strains.

column7: Isolation and characterization of novel bacteriophage-host systems from the closed gold mine Zloty Stok.
column8: The study aimed to characterize five natural parasite-host systems - lytic bacteriophages vB_AspA_Bolek, vB_AspA_Lolek and vB_AspA_Tola infecting different Aeromonas strains, lytic phage vB_Psp_MiKi infecting Pseudomonas sp. MK-20.2.1 and the temperate phage VarioGold induced from the genome of Variovorax sp. ZS18.2.2 with mitomycin C. The bacterial strains and phages described in the research were isolated from arsenic-containing microbial mats and biofilms collected from the closed Zloty Stok gold mine (Poland). At the nucleotide sequence level, phages showed little similarity to sequences available in public databases, suggesting to recognize them as novel viral species (Bolek, Lolek, Tola) and genra (MiKi, VarioGold), respectively. To the best of our knowledge, VarioGold represents the first characterized virus for the Variovorax genus. TEM micrographs analysis of viral preparations revealed capsid morphology typical of podoviruses (Bolek, Lolek, Tola, MiKi) and siphoviruses (VarioGold). All phages were host-specific, with a host range possibly restricted to individual strains inhabiting the mine. An attempt to find a non-lysogenic host for VarioGold was unsuccessful, therefore its further characterization was limited to in-silico analysis. Functional investigation of the Bolek, Lolek, Tola and MiKi phages included examining the ability to propagate under various temperature conditions, the rate of their adsorption to host cells and estimation of the latency time and burst size during one-step growth analysis. In the case of MiKi, the estimation of the burst size turned out problematic due to the irregular, prolonged replication cycle. Explaining the observed phenomenon requires further examination. The presented research significantly enriches the existing knowledge about the general diversity of phages infecting Beta- and Gammaproteobacteria and the impact of viruses on shaping natural microbiocoenoses.

column7: Combined use of paclitaxel and novel mitosis inhibitors as a potential anticancer strategy
column8: The key function of the microtubules and mitotic spindle in cell division (also determining the potential of cancer cells to proliferate) make them an important target in cancer therapy. Therefore, microtubule-targeting agents (MTAs) remain the most important class of conventional chemotherapeutics. However, narrow therapeutic index and multidrug resistance encourage the search for new drugs or new strategies to improve anticancer therapy outcomes and decrease side effects. Taxanes (paclitaxel, PTX), docetaxel, and carbasitaxel), which belong to MTAs, have revolutionized the therapy of solid tumors. However, their hydrophobic nature as well as peripheral neuropathies are among the major limitations and adverse effects of taxane therapy. Combining taxanes with tubulin polymerization inhibitors is one of the strategies that increase the effectiveness of treatment. However, this approach involves high-dose administration of chemotherapeutic agents and causes many side effects. It was recently shown (both in vitro and in vivo) that a combination of low and safe doses of PTX and tubulin polymerization inhibitors (but also clinically insignificant doses when the compounds are used alone) is a promising strategy that allows to the reduction of toxicity.  This study is aimed to evaluate the effect of novel pyridine (S1, S22) and benzofuran (13b, 14) inhibitors of tubulin polymerization on the anticancer properties of low doses of PTX. the anticancer effect of compounds applied in combination with PTX was evaluated against the melanoma A375 and cervical HeLa cell line. PrestoBlue assay was used to the identification of optimal concentrations of combination systems (PTX + S1/S2/13b/14), which exhibited significantly greater (compared to individual compounds) anticancer activity against cervical HeLa cancer cells.

column7: Impact of mRNA modifications and stability on cellular quiescence
column8: Quiescence is the state of a cell in which its proliferation is reversibly arrested while maintaining the ability to re-enter the cell cycle. The mechanisms by which this state is achieved and sustained, as well as their universality between different organisms are mostly unknown. In previous studies of cell proliferation and quiescence, yeast models have proven to be excellent model organisms. They are susceptible to genetic modifications, can easily attain the state of quiescence through nutritional limitations and many of their cellular mechanisms are in correspondence with those in mammalian cells. Consequently, better characterization of these mechanisms could contribute to our understanding of cell functions and to new discoveries concerning human health, including cancer and degenerative diseases research. This particular study focuses on the effects of mRNA modifications and stability on the quiescence state of Schizosaccharomyces pombe yeast cells achieved with the deficit of nitrogen source. The main objective of the experiment is the examination of the survivability and recovery from quiescence in S. pombe cells, as well as the effects of cytoplasmic mRNA degradation on cellular quiescence by exploring yeast mutants associated with processes such as uridylation (Δcid1), 5' mRNA degradation (Δlsm1), 3' RNA degradation (Δski2) or poly(A) tail binding (Δpabp). So far, the obtained results have shown a discrepancy between quiescence survival rates and recovery time between different deletion strains, with the lowest values for Δlsm1 strain and double deletion mutant Δcid1Δlsm1. Morphological differences were also observed. Previous studies have succeeded in identifying and characterizing a number of genes responsible for the entry and maintenance of quiescence which had links to cellular functions in the cytoplasm, membrane and nucleus. This particular study will possibly help to further explore some of these genes related to molecular mRNA modifications.

column7: Synergistic Action of Metal Nanoparticle Complexes in Combating Mastitis in Dairy Cattle: In Vitro Studies and Clinical Perspectives
column8: In the face of increasing pathogen resistance to antibiotics in mastitis, novel effective treatment strategies are sought. Research conducted on metal nanoparticle complexes has demonstrated their biocidal potential against less common mastitis pathogens such as yeast and algae of the genus Prototheca sp. Results from in vitro experiments have shown that complexes such as AgCuNPs and AgAuNPs effectively reduce pathogen viability, with their action potentially being synergistic compared to individual nanoparticles. The high efficacy of metal nanoparticle complexes, particularly AgCuNPs, in reducing mastitis pathogen viability suggests their potential use as alternatives to antibiotics. Further in vivo studies are necessary to confirm these findings and assess their practical effectiveness. The synergy of metal nanoparticle complex action may open new therapeutic possibilities in combating mastitis in dairy cattle.

column7: INFLUENCE OF POSTTRANSCRIPTIONAL MODIFICATIONS ON RNA STRUCTURES: CRYSTALLOGRAPHIC AND THERMODYNAMIC ANALYSIS
column8: The ubiquity of the RNA’s functions comes from its structural richness derived from four nucleotides (A, C, G, U) and their canonical pairing. Furthermore, posttranscriptional modifications of nucleotides extend the possibilities of RNA folding, and thus the spectrum of structural variations. Among modifications, pseudouridine (ψ) is considered the most abundant one and is present in all RNA classes (mRNA, tRNA, ncRNA and rRNA), across all three domains of life[1]. The N1-methylpseudouridine (m1Ψ) has been identified in eucaryotic rRNA, and in archaeal tRNA and rRNA[1]. Moreover, it has been incorporated into COVID-19 mRNA vaccines to improve their efficiency[2]. Comparison of the three-dimensional models of modified sequences to their ‘native’ counterparts can help describe the impact of the modification on RNA structure and function. Hence, conducting more crystallographic studies on RNA molecules is crucial, particularly given their limited number. Here, we present the crystallographic and thermodynamic analysis of unmodified RNA model structures (RNA1-U; RNA2-U, RNA3-U) which serve as references for modified (RNA1-ψ; RNA2-ψ; RNA3-ψ RNA1-m1ψ; RNA2-m1ψ; RNA3-m1ψ) crystal models.  Moreover, the UV-melting analysis and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) were employed to calculate the thermodynamic parameters of native RNA duplexes. column7: Illuminating the Darkness: Deciphering Early Stages of Deetiolation in Arabidopsis
column8: The existence of life on Earth is made possible by the conversion of solar energy into more easily available chemical energy through photosynthesis. This complex biochemical reaction serves as the primary energy source for plants, algae, and certain bacteria, which in turn provide sustenance for other organisms. As such, comprehending the process of photosynthesis is fundamental to our understanding of life on our planet. Biosynthesis of photosynthetic apparatus is a complex, multi-step process requiring considerable amounts of chemical energy. To conserve resources angiosperms delay this process until first exposition to photosynthetically useful light ranging from 400 to 700 nm. The state before the first light exposition is known as etiolation. It is characterised by elongation of cotyledons, leaf underdevelopment, and pale yellow colour (absence of chloroplasts). The process of deetiolation is initiated by exposure to light, which triggers a series of biochemical reactions and cellular rearrangements. Despite extensive research on photosynthesis, the early stages of deetiolation remain somewhat elusive. To shed light on the initial steps of deetiolation, we conducted extensive research on Arabidopsis thaliana (L.) mutants with disrupted pathways related to photosynthesis. Our investigation involved gene expression analysis utilizing quantitative PCR, low-temperature fluorescence to examine photosystem formation, high-performance liquid chromatography for porphyrin and xanthophyll biosynthesis, and in vivo fluorescence imaging to determine maximum photosystem quantum yield during the first 24 hours of deetiolation. We focused particularly on the first four hours of the process. Our approach yielded new insights into the early stages of deetiolation, laying the groundwork for a better understanding of the formation of photosynthetic apparatus. column7: CRYSTALLOGRAPHIC ANALYSIS OF HEXANUCLEOTIDE REPEAT EXPANSION GGGGCC (G4C2) IN RNA MOLECULES ASSOCIATED WITH PATHOGENESIS OF ALS/FTD.
column8: RNA molecules containing G4C2 repeats have been linked to the pathogenesis of two neurodegenerative diseases: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) and Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD). ALS is characterized by the death of motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, while FTD is defined by the loss of neurons in the frontal lobe and temporal lobe of the brain. G4C2 hexanucleotide repeats are located in the non-coding region of the C9orf72 gene. They can over-multiply leading to the development of ALS/FTD. Transcripts of the C9orf72 gene also contain multiplied hexanucleotide repeats and can adopt complex secondary and tertiary structures, including hairpin structures or tetraplex structures. The presented investigations are focused on structural analysis of RNA containing G4C2 repeats, using x-ray diffraction methods. The RNA oligomers were chemically synthesized and crystallized. The x-ray diffraction data were collected at synchroton in Hamburg. The processed data was further used for structure solving. During my presentation, I will discuss the details of this process and show 3D models of the G4C2 RNA repeats.

column7: Application of bacterial cellulose in the process of  cryopreservation of the high-yield strains
column8: Cryopreservation is a method of storing various types of biomaterials by freezing and storing them at low temperatures. To prevent cell damage associated with the formation of ice crystals, cryoprotectants are added, which are intended to lower the freezing point of water.  An ideal cryoprotectant should demonstrate low toxicity, lack of reactivity, high solubility, and permeability. An alternative to currently used substances may be bacterial cellulose (BC). It is a biopolymer produced by various strains of microorganisms, characterized by biocompatibility, non-toxicity, and high strength. The aim of the study was to apply BC as a protective substance for bacteria cells subjected to cryopreservation. Biomass of 3 microorganisms was used for the research: Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Candida albicans. BC was obtained by culturing Komagataeibacter xylinus bacteria, then subjected to purification and grinding to obtain powder. In addition to BC, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and glycerol were used as cryoprotectants in concentrations of 5%, 10%, and 20% in the experiments. The number of viable cells after cryopreservation and incubation lasting 7, 14, 21, and 28 days at a temperature of -80ºC was evaluated. The results showed that the number of viable cells after cryopreservation with the addition of BC was comparable to the trials with the addition of DMSO and glycerol. BC used at concentrations of 5%, 10%, and 20% achieved the best results at the level of 100% viable cells after 7 days of storage. With longer incubation, the viability of E. coli cells stored with the addition of BC was on average 30% higher compared to DMSO or glycerol, while the viability of C. albicans cells was comparable (average of 100%) for all substances. It was shown that BC acts more effectively as a cryoprotective agent for S. aureus cells than glycerol, as a result 20% higher for BC was obtained. The study demonstrated that BC could potentially be used as a cryoprotectant.

column7: Low-frequency electromagnetic field (50 Hz, 1.5 mT, 24h, 48h) can influence “stem cell fate”
column8: Background: Electromagnetic field can affect the biology and cellular processes (such as proliferation, differentiation, cell cycle, and metabolism) of mesenchymal stem cells and thus modulate their “fate”. Researchers unveiled its positive and negative impact on cells depending on parameters and time of exposure. In search of stem cell-based therapy, it can be used as a preconditioning factor for regenerative medicine purposes. Therefore, it seems crucial to understand how electromagnetic field, in specific parameters and doses, impact stem cell biology.  Methods: Commercially available, human adipose-derived stem cells were exposed continuously to low-frequency electromagnetic fields (50 Hz; 1.5 mT) in vitro. After 24 and 48 hours, total RNA was isolated, and complementary DNA was synthesized. Next, Tuj-1, Sox9, Runx2, and Numb gene expression were analyzed with the quantitative PCR method. Data were analyzed with one-way ANOVA using the Tukey test. Results: Electromagnetic field (50 Hz; 1.5 mT) can statistically significantly influence the expression of Tuj 1 gene, which is related to neurogenesis after 48h of stimulation. Moreover, it impacts chondrogenic gene expression such as Sox9 after 24 and 48 hours of exposure. However, it does not affect significantly the osteogenic marker expression Runx2 as well as the Numb gene expression associated with the symmetric and asymmetric stem cell division pathway. Conclusions: Tested electromagnetic doses may “force” ASCs to redefine their stem cell fate, alter their reprogramming decision, and initiate differentiation processes. It is even more interesting, that morphologically it is unidentifiable. Further research on differentiation markers and the analysis of cellular pathways such as Notch-Numb involved in cell division should be conducted.

column7: Metastatic properties of three murine breast cancer sublines
column8: Cancer is one of the main causes of death. The lethal nature of the disease in 90% of cases is determined by metastases. The ability to undergo metastasis results from a number of metabolic, genetic and epigenetic changes in cancer cells and the tumor microenvironment. The complexity of the metastasis process and its multi-stage nature have been better understood thanks to mouse cancer models. We have used weakly metastasizing breast cancer line E0771, and its two modified sublines with increased migratory abilities (E0771 TGF-β and 24x2). The aim of the study was to investigate the kinetics of the formation and development of spontaneous metastases in the three sublines of orthotopically grown tumors in C57BL/6 mice. The ability of the three sublines to migrate and be invasive was checked using plates with Transwell inserts. Then, the cells were inoculated orthotopically into the breast fat-pads of female C56BL/6 mice to determine the kinetics of formation and the number of micrometastases in vivo. For this purpose, mice were euthanized and tumors, lungs and livers were isolated. Tissues were analyzed macroscopically, histologically and by seeding isolated cells for clonal analysis. Our results confirmed the greater migratory capacity of TGF-β and 24x2 subline cells. We noticed more metastases accumulating in the lung than in the liver. In the lung, their size  increased linearly with time, while in the liver the increase was less steep. First metastases appear in the lung already a week after the inoculation of cancer cells into the breast fat-pad. The expression of cell migration markers: SNAIL-1, vimentin and CD43 correlated with the invasiveness in vivo. The results provide the basis for a better understanding of the course of the metastatic cascade.. We have shown that it is influenced by inflammatory factors like TGF-β and mechanic selection of cells able to pass through pores, and that increased metastatic ability is connected to more mesenchymal phenotype.

column7: Microtissue Engineering in hydrogel microdroplets generated in high-throughput
column9: Droplet microfluidics-based technologies for microtissue engineering are gaining great popularity. However, balancing throughput, droplet monodispersity and even crosslinking is challenging. In our setup, we can produce more than 10000 crosslinked hydrogel droplets of ~200 µm diameter within 2 minutes with 50 cells per droplet on average. Briefly, our system consisted of a droplet-generation chip with multiple parallel channels for fabricating droplets with encapsulated cells. These droplets were carried by the continuous phase (oil-surfactant) to a crosslinking chip placed before an LED UV lamp. Post-washing these crosslinked droplets were placed for long-term culture. This system was used for various applications like encapsulation of pancreatic β-cells for Type-I diabetes therapy and co-encapsulation of leukemia with bone marrow stroma cells for drug-resistance analysis. For a complex droplet-in-droplet system, the droplets (“cores”) were collected post-washing and mixed with another uncrosslinked hydrogel solution containing cells and were passed through a T-junction channel chip to form the “shell”. These complex systems were used for disease modeling and drug testing using cancer cells and fibroblasts as a novel application.
